fields.text: Does your institution have a trauma program?
fields.help_text: This first question has help text.

fields.text: Is there a resolution within the past three years supporting the trauma program from the hospital governing body e.g. the hospital board?
Is there a medical staff resolution within the past three years supporting the trauma program?
Is there specific budgetary support for the trauma program such as personnel, education and equipment?
Is there a clear defined line of reporting for the TMD within the organization?
Are there regional or state efforts to create a trauma system?
Does the hospital trauma program staff participate in the state and/or regional trauma system planning, development, or operation?
Does the trauma program leadership (TMD, TPM) have the authority to develop, oversee and improve the care of the injured within the facility?
Does your trauma program have a Trauma Program Operational Review Committee?
Does your trauma program have Trauma Peer Review Committee Meetings?
Does your trauma program have a trauma medical director?

Is the TMD a board-certified or board-eligible general surgeon (pediatric surgery in          a pediatric facility) and in good standing in the institution with state licensure, has membership in professional organizations?
Does the TMD participate in trauma call?
Does the TMD lead the trauma QI and patient safety program within the trauma center?
What level of education does your trauma program manager have?
Does the TMD have a method to identify injured patients, monitor the provision of health care services, make periodic rounds, and hold formal and informal discussions with individual practitioners?
Does the TMD perform annual review of the performance of all surgeons on          the trauma call panel?
Does the TMD have the ability to contribute to the trauma program manager’s performance evaluation?
Is the TMD a member of national or regional trauma organizations?
Does your TMD have the required verifiable 18 hours of Category I trauma-specific CME, or 18 hours of trauma-specific internal education every three years?
Does the TMD have sufficient authority to set the qualifications for the trauma service members?
Does the structure of the trauma program allow the TMD to have oversight and authority for the care of injured patients who may be admitted to individual surgeons?
Does the TMD have the authority to appoint members to the trauma panel?
Does your institution have a trauma program manager?

Is the TPM an RN that has responsibility for monitoring and evaluating nursing care of the trauma patients and coordination of QI and patient safety programs for the trauma center in conjunction with the TMD?
Does the trauma program manager show evidence of educational preparation, continuing trauma education and clinical experience in the care of injured patients?
Is the TPM current in ATCN, TNCC, or an equivalent course certifications current?
If your TPM is new to the position (less than 6 months) has he/she registered to take a QI course, and an AIS coding course or state sponsored coding course?
Is your  facilities TPM  at least 1.0 FTE, if trauma patient record volume is 500 or greater?
Who does the TPM report to?
List the number of FTE of support personnel.
Does your institution have a trauma registrar?
Does your Trauma Registrar have a job description?
Is the Registrar a full-time position?
Has the Registrar attended the AAAM course or a state sponsored coding course?
Does your trauma program have official physician liaisons in EM, orthopedics, neurosurgery, anesthesia, critical care, and radiology?
Do the liaisons disseminate information from the trauma meetings back to their service members?
Do your liaisons attend 50% of the Trauma Program Operational Review Committee meetings and 50% of the Trauma Peer Review Committee Meetings?

Is there a predetermined set of care providers and ancillary personnel (physicians, mid-level practitioners, nurses, X-ray technologists, laboratory, respiratory therapists, etc.) needed to provide resuscitation, rapid triage, and transfer or the severely injured?
Does your facility provide 24/7 general surgical coverage?
Number of trauma surgeons taking call
Do all of the trauma panel surgeons have privileges in general surgery?
Are all of the general surgeons (trauma surgeons on call panel) board-certified/eligible* or a FACS or FACO?
Have all general surgeons on the trauma team successfully completed the ATLS course at least once?
What percent of general surgeons are current in ATLS?
Do all the trauma surgeons who take trauma call have documented 18 hours if Category I trauma specific CME or 18 hours of trauma-specific internal education every three years?
Have they participated in an internal education process conducted by the trauma program based on the principles of practice-based learning?
Has the 'Core' group of trauma surgeons been adequately defined by the trauma medical director?
Does the 'Core' group take at least 60% of the total trauma call hours each month?
Does the 'Core' group each participate in 50% of the Trauma Peer Review Committee meetings and  disseminate information back to all non-core surgeons?
What is the number of 'Core' trauma surgeons?
What is the number of 'Non-core' trauma surgeons taking call?
Is the trauma surgeon dedicated to the trauma center while on call?
Do trauma surgeons take in-house call?
Does the trauma surgeon provide care for non-trauma emergencies when on call?
Is there a published backup call schedule for the trauma surgeons?
Number of trauma surgeons with added certifications in critical care?
Number of trauma fellowship-trained surgeons on call panel?
Does your facility provide 24/7 orthopedic coverage.  On-call and promptly available when requested by the trauma surgeon or EM specialist?
Is there an orthopedic surgeon who is identified as the liaison to the trauma program?

Have the orthopedic surgeons documented at least an average of 18 hours in three years of verifiable Category I trauma-specific CME, or 18 hours of trauma-specific internal education every three years?
Does the orthopedic surgeon liaison participate in 50% of the Trauma Peer Review Committee meetings and disseminate information back to all orthopedic surgeons on the call panel?
Number of orthopedic surgeons on the trauma call panel?
Are all of the orthopedic surgeons who care for injured patients board-certified/eligible or a Fellow of an organization?
Do all of the orthopedic surgeons have privileges in general orthopedic surgery?
Are the on-call orthopedic surgeons dedicated to the hospital (i.e. Do not take call simultaneously at  another hospital?
In the case where the orthopedic is not dedicated to the facility 24/7, does your facility have orthopedic backup plan?
Is the back-up plan approved by your TMD?
Are plastic surgery, hand surgery, microvascular surgery, and spinal injury care capabilities present at this Level I trauma center?
Is there an orthopedic team member promptly available in the trauma resuscitation area when consulted by the surgical trauma team leader for multiple injured patients?
Does facility have an orthopedic surgery residency program?
Does the facility have an orthopedic trauma fellowship?
Are there physical and occupational therapists and rehabilitation specialists involved in the acute and rehabilitation phases of care?
Do you provide 24/7 neurosurgical coverage.  On-call promptly available when requested by the trauma surgeon or EM specialist?
Is there a designated neurosurgeon liaison?
What is the number of neurosurgeons on the call panel?
Are there physicians with special competence in caring for the patient with neuro trauma in house and immediately available?
Do the other neurosurgeons who take trauma call have verifiable 18 hours of Category I trauma-specific CME, or 18 hours of trauma-specific internal education every 3 years?
Does the neurosurgeon liaison participate in 50% of the Trauma Peer Review Committee and disseminate information back to all neurosurgeons on the call panel.
Are the neurosurgeons dedicated to this hospital when on trauma call (i.e. - not taking simultaneous call at another hospital)?
In the case where the neurosurgeon is not dedicated to the facility 24/7, does your facility have neurosurgical backup plan?
Is the back-up plan published and approved by your TMD?
Does the facility have a neurosurgery residency program?
Are qualified neurosurgeons regularly involved in the care of head - and spinal cord - injured patients and are credentialed by the hospital with general neurosurgical privileges?
Is there a trauma-director approved plan that determines which types and severity of neurologic injury patients should remain at the facility when no neurosurgical coverage is present?
Is anesthesia available in-house 24/7. (This may be fulfilled by an anesthesiologist, PGY4 or greater anesthesia resident or a CRNA)?
Are anesthesiology services promptly available for emergency operations 24/7?
Are anesthesiology services promptly available for airway problems?
Is there a fully credentialed anesthesia provider present for all trauma operations?
Is there an anesthesiologist liaison designated to the trauma program?
Is the availability of the anesthesia services and the absence of delays in airway control or operations documented by the trauma QI program?
Number of anesthesiologists on staff?
Have all of the anesthesiologists taking call successfully completed an anesthesiology residency?

When anesthesiology chief residents or CRNAs are used to fulfill availability requirements, are the staff anesthesiologists on call advised, promptly available at all times, and present for all operat
In a Level II trauma center without in-house anesthesia services (house wide), are protocols in place to ensure the timely arrival at the bedside of the anesthesia provider?
In a Level II trauma center without in-house anesthesia services, is there documentation of the presence of physicians skilled in emergency airway management?
Does the hospital use CRNAs?
Are the CRNAs credentialed by the hospital to begin an emergency case without MD presence?
Do you have a liaison from the EM Service to the Trauma Program who effective disseminating information back to the EM service?
Is there a designated emergency physician available to the trauma director for QI issues that occur in the emergency department?
Does the EM liaison have the required verifiable 18 hours of Category I trauma- specific CME, or 18 hours of trauma-specific internal education every three years.
The EM liaison regularly attends 50% of the trauma QI meeting and has documented 50% attendance at  the Trauma Peer Review Committee meetings.
Number of emergency physicians who treat major trauma patients?
Have all of the emergency physicians successfully completed the ATLS course at least once?
What percent of ED physicians are current in ATLS?
Are there any physicians who are not board certified in emergency medicine who work in the emergency department.
Are physicians that are non-boarded in emergency medicine current in ATLS?
Are emergency department physicians present in the emergency department at all times?
Is there an emergency medicine residency program?
Are the roles of emergency physicians and trauma surgeons defined, agreed on, and approved by the director of trauma services?
Are all of the emergency physicians who care for injured patients board-certified/eligible?
Does coverage of out of department emergencies such as “code blue” or ICU calls leave the emergency department without appropriate physician coverage?
Describe the credentialing requirements for nurses who treat trauma patients in the ED:
For this Level I or Level II center, are all of the following medical specialists available?
For this Level I center, are all of the following surgical specialists available?
In this Level II facility, are specialists from internal medicine, pediatrics, nephrology, hematology, cardiology available on staff?
In this Level II facility, are specialty consultants from internal medicine, pediatrics and radiology on call and promptly available?
For this Level II center, are all of the following surgical specialists available 24/7?
Does your emergency department (ED) have a designated emergency physician director supported by additional physicians to ensure immediate care for injured patients?
Does your ED have an ED nursing liaison available to the trauma team?
Does your ED have a method to communicate changes in trauma process to all staff members caring for injured patients?
Are you seeking a pre-assessment for a trauma center or a trauma system?
If Trauma Center, which level?
What will be your next step of review:
Date of most recent review if one has occurred (mm/yyyy):
Give the location of your institution?
Tax Status (ownership  public vs private)
Is there is a Medical School Affiliation?
Describe the air medical support services available in the area and the type:
Does your institution serve as a base station for EMS operations?
Does your institution provide medical direction?
Is a trauma program representative involved in pre-hospital training?
Does a trauma program representative participate in pre-hospital protocol development?
Is there a representative from the emergency department that participates in a QI program with pre-hospital providers?
Is there a clear defined line of reporting for the TPM within the organization?
What is the medical speciality of your TMD?
Who does the TMD report to?
Which national or regional trauma organization is your TMD a member of?
Does the TMD have the authority to remove members from the trauma panel?
